author. 1 0009–0009-9581–5475 2 0009–0009-5736–8352 3 0000–0002-8203–6546 In this work, we report metal-metalloid Pd2B alloy nanoparticles as highly efficient and selective catalysts for semi-hydrogenations of alkynes. The mentioned materials feature the residence of small Pd2B nanoparticles in the cavities of hollow mesoporous silica nanospheres (Pd2B@HMSNs), and were synthesized by in situ transformation of Pd@HMSNs with B sources. At near room temperatures and atmospheric H2 pressure, Pd2B@HMSNs exhibited high alkene selectivity for hydrogenations of a series of alkynes. Especially, such high alkene selectivity can be maintained with a prolonged reaction time, and nearly 100 % selectivity of cis to trans alkene is obtained for those internal alkynes. The excellent performance of Pd2B@HMSNs is originated from the residence of catalytic functionality inside hollow nanostructures and the change of electronic/geometric properties of surface Pd species by alloying with B, where the former improves their reusability and the latter suppresses the deep-hydrogenation of alkenes. Graphical Abstract Keywords Hollow nanoreactors Semi-hydrogenation Alkyne Mesoporous silica Metal-metalloid alloy Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Various fine chemicals, such as vitamins [1], perfumes [2,3] and pharmaceuticals [4,5], can be manufactured by semi-hydrogenations of alkynes. However, the intermediate alkenes will be quickly converted to the unwanted alkanes due to their easy hydrogenations. To improve the alkene selectivity for real applications and advance the rational design of selective catalysts, developing highly efficient alkyne semi-hydrogenation catalysts is desired. The current industrial process employs the poisoning strategy to improve the selectivity of noble metal catalysts for semi-hydrogenations of alkynes. The typical example is the Lindlar catalysts, Pd/CaCO3 treated by Pb salts and with addition of quinolone. Through the poisoning by Pb and quinolone, the Lindlar catalysts improve the selectivity of alkenes, where the ligand coordination and lead poisoning tailor the electronic and geometric structures of surface metals to improve the alkene selectivity. The similar poisoning strategy using ligands containing S [6–8] or N [9,10] atoms to enhance the semi-hydrogenation has been reported in literatures. For example, pyrene-thiol derivative-modified Pd nanoparticles (NPs) promote the semi-hydrogenation of phenylacetylene to styrene [6] while Pt NPs with the addition of octylamine could allow the hydrogenation of 4-octyn to 4-octene but block the hydrogenation of 4-octene to 4-octane [11]. In general, addition of ligands is required during recycling experiments for such a ligand poisoning strategy. Another methodology to improve the semi-hydrogenations of alkynes is to alloy noble metals with non-precious metals. In this strategy, the interaction between metals modifies the electronic and geometric structures of noble metal surfaces, and further inhibits the adsorption of alkenes to avoid their deep hydrogenation. Among various non-precious metals, Bi [12], Zn [13], Ni [14,15], Ag [16,17], and Cu [18,19], have been selected for alloying with Pd to improve the selectivity of semi-hydrogenations of alkynes. Although alloying noble metals with non-precious metals could enhance the selectivity of alkene formation to more or less degrees, the example of keeping the high alkene selectivity during a prolonged reaction time is rarely reported [4]. Relative to non-precious metals as the second metal for alloying, the use of metalloids and non-metals, such as B [20–22], P [23–25], Te [26–28], and Sb [29,30], are significantly less. Theoretical calculations indicate that B could enhance the coking resistance when alloyed with Ni [31] or Co [32] while alloying Pt sub-nano-clusters with boron is predicted to improve the catalytic stability for H2-related reactions [33]. Though alloying metals with metalloids is predicted to enhance the catalytic performance for some reactions, the controlled synthesis of such alloys is quite difficult. The major challenging is the significantly different reduction potentials between metals and metalloids, which makes it difficult to form alloy by co-reduction. Very recently, the controlled synthesis of noble metal/B alloys achieved a big progress, and mesoporous PdB nanospheres with diameters of ∼ 100 nm have been successfully prepared by a solvothermal method [34]. Such B-containing noble metal-based alloys exhibited enhanced performance for catalytic reduction [34] and electro-catalysis [35–37], suggesting that the metal-metalloid alloys may open up a new reservoir for selective catalysts. In this study, we design hollow mesoporous silica nanospheres-encaged Pd2B alloy NPs (Pd2B@HMSNs) for alkyne hydrogenation, and the mentioned metal-metalloid alloys function as highly efficient semi-hydrogenation catalysts for a series of alkynes. The prepared Pd2B@HMSNs feature small Pd2B alloy NPs inside high specific surface area hollow mesoporous silica nanospheres, and demonstrate 93–100 % of alkene selectivity at 100 % of conversions for hydrogenations of 2-butyn-1-ol, 3-hexyn-1-ol, 2-methyl-3-butyne-2-ol and 3-methyl-1-pentyn-3-ol. Particularly for internal alkynes (2-butyn-1-ol and 3-hexyn-1-ol), the yields of cis-alkene can reach 98–100 %. Moreover, Pd2B@HMSNs are recyclable with less degradation, and the high selectivity could be maintained even with a significantly prolonged reaction time. The excellent catalytic performance of Pd2B@HMSNs is attributed to their unique nanostructures and the synergistic effect between Pd and B. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis, characterization and the enhanced performances of Pd2B@HMSNs for semi-hydrogenations of alkynes The Pd2B@HMSNs were synthesized by in situ transformation of Pd@HMSNs by a solvothermal method using borane dimethylamine complex (DMAB) as B source while the precursor Pd@HMSNs were prepared by a modified method reported in our previous work [38]. The mentioned solvothermal method has been used to synthesize ∼ 100 nm mesoporous Pd2B nanospheres [34]. In this study, the combination of the use of Pd@HMSNs and in situ alloying Pd with B source ensures the preserving of small size of catalytic functionality and the residence of Pd2B NPs inside the central cavities. Scheme 1 shows the corresponding synthetic procedures. We used the micelles of poly(ethylenimine) (PEI) and poly (acrylic acid) (PAA) as templates for hydrolysis of tetramethoxysilane (TMOS) to obtain PEI-PAA@SiO2, which further adsorbed Pd2+ ions by immersing them in Pd2+ solution to give PEI-PAA-Pd2+@SiO2. After calcination at 400 or 500 °C (to obtain PdO@HMSNs) and following H2 reduction at 200 °C, the precursor Pd@HMSNs were obtained, and subsequent transformation of Pd@HMSNs with DMAB in tetrahydrofuran resulted in Pd2B@HMSNs. It is mentioned here that the micelle templates are formed due to the cross-linkage of positively charged PEI and negatively charged PAA by electrostatic attraction. For clarity, Pd@HMSNs prepared by calcination at 400 °C and following H2-reduction at 200 °C are named as Pd@HMSNs-400–200 while those prepared by calcination at 500 °C and subsequent H2-reduction at 200 °C are named as Pd@HMSNs-500–200, where the Pd loadings of Pd@HMSNs-400–200 and Pd@HMSNs-500–200 are 0.22 and 0.29 wt% determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES), respectively. The Pd loadings of Pd2B@HMSNs prepared from the boronation of Pd@HMSNs-400–200 and Pd@HMSNs-500–200 are 0.27 and 0.30 wt%, respectively. It is mentioned here that different calcination temperatures will cause the different amounts of organic residues in Pd@HMSNs, which further causes the different Pd loadings in Pd2B@HMSNs. Fig. 1a shows high angle annular dark field scanning transition electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images of Pd2B@HMSNs prepared by the boronation of Pd@HMSNs-400–200 while their transition electron microscopy (TEM) images and size analysis of inner Pd2B NPs are shown in Figure S1 and S2, respectively. Due to high contrast between silica and Pd2B in the dark-field model, the residence of small Pd2B NPs inside the large cavities of hollow silica nanospheres is clearly observed in Fig. 1a while those inner small Pd2B NPs are not visible in the corresponding bright field TEM images (Figure S1a and S1b). The average particle size of inner NPs is ∼ 6 nm, and total nanospheres are ∼ 130 nm with ∼ 95 nm of central cavities (Figure S2). The lattice spacing of 0.236 nm in the insert of Fig. 1a is attributed to the spacing of (002) of hcp Pd2B, suggesting the formation of Pd2B. Fig. 1b presents X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of various Pd2B@HMSNs with different Pd loadings. Due to the extremely low Pd loading of 0.27 wt% of Pd2B@HMSNs prepared from the boronation of Pd@HMSNs-400–200, their XRD patterns only show the silica diffractions (the blue patterns). Therefore, we prepared a series of Pd@HMSNs with higher Pd loadings by soaking PEI-PAA@SiO2 in more concentrated Pd2+ ion solutions, and following 400 °C calcination and 200 °C H2-reduction to give Pd@HMSNs were constant. Subsequently, the boronation of Pd@HMSNs with different Pd loadings will result in Pd2B@HMSNs with various Pd loadings. As shown in Fig. 1b, the green patterns of Pd2B@HMSNs with a Pd loading of 0.53 wt% (the corresponding Pd@HMSNs were prepared from 1.4 times more concentrated Pd2+ ion solutions) show a peak at 2θ degree of ∼ 41.3, which can be assigned to the (101) diffraction of orthorhombically distorted hcp structure of Pd2B [39]. Moreover, the (111) diffraction of fcc Pd at 2θ degree of 40.1 doesn’t appear, suggesting the complete transformation of Pd into Pd2B. Continuously increasing the Pd loadings of Pd2B@HMSNs to 0.77 wt% (the corresponding Pd@HMSNs were prepared from double concentrated Pd2+ ion solutions) results in a more intense (101) diffraction of hcp Pd2B (the red patterns). Further using 10 times more concentrated Pd2+ ion solutions to prepare Pd@HMSNs for the boronation to synthesize Pd2B@HMSNs illustrates well-defined hcp Pd2B structures (the dark patterns), where the (100), (002), (101), (102), (110) and (103) diffractions [39] of hcp Pd2B are all clearly visible. The insert of Fig. 1b presents the structures of hcp Pd2B, where Pd atoms stack as an hcp sequence of ABABAB (blue and green), and boron atoms (red) fill in the hole of octahedral Pd6. By alloying with B, the Pd-Pd distance in Pd2B and the surface electronic/geometric properties are apparently different from individual fcc Pd. It is mentioned here that, for those materials with extremely low metal loadings, characterizations of them are very difficult. Since the synthetic conditions of the materials in Fig. 1b were same, and the difference is the concentrations of Pd2+ ion solutions for soaking PEI-PAA@SiO2, we speculate that no appearance of hcp structure of Pd2B for Pd2B@HMSNs prepared from Pd@HMSNs-400–200 is due to their extremely low Pd loading of 0.27 wt%. Fig. 2a to d present hydrogenations of hydroxyl group-substituted internal and terminal alkynes over Pd2B@HMSNs prepared from the boronation of Pd@HMSNs-400–200 under atmospheric H2 pressure and low temperatures. As shown in Fig. 2a, the yields of cis-2-buten-1-ol reach 98 % with 100 % conversion of 2-butyn-1-ol at 195 min, and the high selectivity of cis-alkene is maintained with a prolonged reaction time. The catalytic performance of Pd2B@HMSNs for hydrogenation of 3-hexyn-1-ol (Fig. 2b) is even better, where the yields of cis-3-hexen-1-ol approach 100 % at a shorter reaction time of 25 min and no reduction of cis-alkene selectivity is observed with an extended reaction time. For hydrogenations of those terminal alkynes, the alkene yields approach 94 and 93 % at complete conversions of 2-methyl-3-butyne-2-ol (Fig. 2c) and 3-methyl-1-pentyn-3-ol (Fig. 2d), respectively, and the alkene selectivity only shows a slight decrease when the reaction time is prolonged. Indeed, Pd2B@HMSNs prepared from the boronation of Pd@HMSNs-400–200 is highly efficient and selective for semi-hydrogenations of alkynes, and the excellent performance should be ascribed to their unique nanostructures and the formation of Pd2B phase. Here, we speculate that the better maintenance of alkene selectivity for hydrogenation of internal alkyne substrates is due to the relatively difficult hydrogenation of internal alkenes while the terminal alkenes could be relatively more easily hydrogenated to the corresponding alkanes due to the less steric hindrance. 2.2 The origin of the enhanced alkene selectivity of Pd2B@HMSNs for hydrogenations of alkynes To determine the origin of the excellent performance of Pd2B@HMSNs prepared from the boronation of Pd@HMSNs-400–200, the Pd@HMSNs-400–200 was first compared for hydrogenation of 2-butyn-1-ol. Although Pd2B@HMSNs prepared from the boronation of Pd@HMSNs-400–200 exhibit good performance for semi-hydrogenation of 2-butyn-1-ol (Fig. 2a), Pd@HMSNs-400–200 is surprisingly non-active. As shown in Fig. 3a, Pd@HMSNs-400–200 only obtains ∼ 7 % of alkyne conversions at 240 min. Interestingly, Pd@HMSNs-500–200 (increasing the calcination temperatures to 500 °C and keeping the constant H2 reduction temperature at 200 °C) showed a much better activity. As shown in Fig. 3c, Pd@HMSNs-500–200 demonstrates the characteristic properties of consecutive reactions, where the yields of alkanes continuously increase and the alkene yields quickly decrease after the maximums of alkene yields are achieved. Considering the only difference of calcination temperatures for Pd@HMSNs-400–200 (Pd loading of 0.22 wt%) and Pd@HMSNs-500–200 (Pd loading of 0.29 wt%), the poor performance of Pd@HMSNs-400–200 for hydrogenation is due to a substantial amount of organic residues in the materials (discuss later), and these organic residues cover the Pd surface and result in low activities. Since increasing the calcination temperatures to 500 °C could basically remove the organic residues, Pd@HMSNs-500–200 demonstrate a good activity, but the alkene selectivity is not good due to the easy hydrogenation of alkenes to alkanes with individual Pd. The HAADF-STEM images of Pd@HMSNs support the above statements. As shown in Fig. 3b, no visible Pd nanoparticles (NPs) were found in Pd@HMSNs-400–200 due to the coverage of Pd NPs with organic residues while Pd NPs were clearly observed in Pd@HMSNs-500–200 in Fig. 3d due to the removal of organic residues. In sharp contrast, not only Pd2B@HMSNs prepared from the boronation of Pd@HMSNs-500–200 show good performance (Figure S1c, S1d and S3), but also the Pd2B@HMSNs prepared from the boronation of Pd@HMSNs-400–200 exhibit good activities and even better alkene selectivity (Fig. 2a), suggesting that the boronation by a solvothermal method could remove organic residues and the formation of Pd2B greatly enhances the alkene selectivity. Indeed, the thermogravimetric/differential thermogravimetric (TG/DTG) analyses, Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra, N2 adsorption-desorption studies and the metal loadings by ICP-OES support removal of organics during the boronation process. Fig. 4a presents the thermogravimetric/differential thermogravimetric (TG/DTG) analyses of PEI-PAA-Pd2+@SiO2 (Pd@HMSNs before calcination). As shown in Fig. 4a, four characteristic peaks at ∼ 60, 230, 320 and 590 °C from DTG analysis are clearly visible. The peak at ∼ 60 °C can be assigned to the evaporation of moisture adsorbed on the materials, and those at 230, 320 and 590 °C are ascribed to the decomposition of organic materials enclosed in the silica. It is mentioned here that DG/DTG experiments were carried out at a fast temperature ramping rate of 10 °C/min while the calcination of the materials in a muffle furnace was performed at a slow heating rate of < 1 °C/min and with keeping at the defined temperatures for 3.0 hrs. Therefore, the residue of organic components should be much less after real calcination. FT-IR studies of various HMSNs before and after calcination in Fig. 4b confirm the above speculation. The FT-IR bands at 1563.5 and 1401.5 cm−1 of PEI-PAA-Pd2+@SiO2 (Pd@HMSNs before calcination) are due to the N-H bending vibration [10] and the symmetric COO stretching vibration of aminated carboxyl [40], respectively, while the peaks at 2851/2970 cm−1 can be assigned to the stretching vibration of C-H [41,42] and that at 1467 cm−1 is ascribed to the bending vibration of C-H [10]. The above mentioned peaks are still observed in the Pd@HMSNs-400–200, suggesting that calcination at 400 °C could not completely remove organic components. However, Pd2B@HMSNs prepared from Pd@HMSNs-400–200 only presents the residue peaks of organic components, indicating that the solvothermal process employed for boronation could further remove organics. Those peaks of organics are invisible for Pd@HMSNs-500–200, indicating complete removal of organics by 500 °C calcination. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of various HMSNs are presented in Fig. 4c. All tested HMSNs show type IV isotherms with hysteresis loops of mesoporous structures [43], and exhibit the enforced enclosures at P/P0 of ∼ 0.46, confirming the hollow nanostructures [44,45]. Fig. 4d illustrates their pore size distributions by the Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Although there are no sharply concentrated mesopores, the apparently high values of dV/dD pore volume indicate the presence of mesopores from 2 to ∼ 10 nm. The pore size distributions of corresponding HMSNs by the non-local density functional theory (NLDFT) method are shown in Figure S4. Indeed, mesoporous pores can be obviously observed for all materials. Table 1 summarizes the textural properties and metal loadings of various HMSNs. As the calcination temperature increased from 400 to 500 °C, the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface areas and pore volumes of Pd@HMSNs significantly increase from 652 (m2/g)/0.69 (cm3/g) to 831 (m2/g)/0.86 (cm3/g), certainly due to the complete removal of organics with 500 °C calcination, which is aligned with a big increase of Pd loadings from 0.22 to 0.29 wt%. As Pd@HMSNs are converted into Pd2B@HMSNs, the BET specific surface areas and pore volumes decrease significantly, possibly due to the blockage of pores and voids by B2O3 produced by decomposition of excess DMAB in the solvothermal method[30]. Although XRD measurements don’t observe the diffractions of B2O3, the relatively high B loading of ∼ 1.5 wt% in the Pd2B@HMSNs prepared from Pd@HMSNs-400–200 suggests the presence of amorphous B2O3. In addition, the boronation increases the Pd loadings from 0.22 wt% of Pd@HMSNs-400–200–0.27 wt% of Pd2B@HMSNs prepared from the boronation of Pd@HMSNs-400–200, confirming that the boronation by the slovothermal method further removes organics. The weight of organics removed during boronation of Pd@HMSNs-400–200 roughly accounts for ∼ 22 wt% of the total weight of Pd@HMSNs-400–200. Such a substantial amount of organics in Pd@HMSNs-400–200 will certainly decrease its catalytic activity due to the coverage of organic residues on Pd NPs. In contrast, Pd2B@HMSNs prepared from Pd@HMSNs-400–200 show a good activity due to the removal of organics during the boronation process. The high selectivity of alkene formation and the preserving of high selectivity with a prolonged reaction time indicate that Pd2B@HMSNs prepared from the boronation of Pd@HMSNs-400–200 could inhibit the alkene adsorption to avoid their deep hydrogenation, and the change of coordination behaviors of alkenes on Pd2B should be originated from their unique electronic and geometric properties induced by alloying. To prove the above speculation, cis-3-hexen-1-ol and 3-methyl-1-penten-3-ol were selected as substrates for hydrogenations. As illustrated in Figs. 5a and 5b, the reactions indeed show no observable conversions for cis-3-hexen-1-ol and a trace conversion for 3-methyl-1-penten-3-ol when alkenes are substrates alone. In contrast, the alkene selectivity for hydrogenation of alkynes over the control Pd@HMSNs-500–200 (Fig. 3c) cannot be maintained, and the yields of alkanes continuously increase after complete conversions of alkynes are achieved. More hydrogenations of alkynes including 2-methyl-3-butyne-2-ol, 3-methyl-1-pentyn-3-ol and 3-hexyn-1-ol over Pd@HMSNs-500–200 are shown in Figure S5a, S5b and S5c, respectively, where alkene selectivity cannot be maintained with the reaction proceeding. Figure S5d shows hydrogenation of cis-3-hexen-1-ol over Pd@HMSNs-500–200, and obvious conversions of alkene to alkane are observed when alkene is used as substrates. Such a sharp difference of alkene hydrogenation between Pd@HMSNs and Pd2B@HMSNs confirms that alloying Pd with B inhibits the adsorption of alkenes to avoid their deep hydrogenation. Diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (DRIFT-IR) with CO probes was employed to investigate the surface coordination behaviors of inner NPs of various HMSNs. In this study, the materials with high loadings of Pd were used to increase the resolution of spectra. As shown in Fig. 5c, the free CO bands above 2100 cm−1 disappear after 10 min of argon purging. The remained CO peaks at 1961 and 1995 cm−1 could be assigned to the bridged CO on (111) and (100) facets of Pd NPs in Pd@HMSNs [46–48], respectively, while that at ∼ 2090 cm−1 is attributed to the linear CO species. Compared with Pd@HMSNs, the CO bands on Pd2B@HMSNs in Fig. 5d present red shifts of 25–28 cm−1, confirming the existence of an electronic effect between Pd and B. These red shifts indicate an increase of the electron densities of surface Pd species, where B donates electron to Pd by alloying. Such a change of the electronic properties by alloying Pd with B alters the coordination behaviors of reactants and products, thus inhibiting the alkene adsorption. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) studies were performed to investigate the Pd and B interaction as well as the valence states of the inner NPs of various HMSNs. To improve the resolution, Pd@HMSNs and Pd2B@HMSNs with high loadings of Pd were used. Fig. 6 presents Pd 3d XPS spectra. The bands at 340.7 and 335.4 eV in Fig. 6a are assigned to 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 of Pd0 species [39] of Pd@HMSNs, respectively, while those at 340.5 and 335.2 eV in Fig. 6b are attributed to 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 of Pd0 species of Pd2B@HMSNs, respectively. A shift of 0.2 eV toward lower binding energies by alloying Pd with B is observed, which has been reported in the previous work [39]. Such a decrease in binding energies confirms the electron flowing from B to Pd, which is consistent with DRIFT-IR studies. The B 1 s spectra are shown in Figure S6a, where the band at 193 eV is assigned to 1 s of the B3+ species and that at 188.8 eV can be attributed to 1 s of the B0 species. Most of B species are present as the oxidized form, and this majority of oxidized B species should be originated from the thermal decomposition of excess DMAB during the boronation process. The B loading of Pd2B@HMSNs prepared from the boronation of Pd@HMSNs-400–200 is ∼ 1.5 wt%, which is significantly higher than the amount required for the formation of Pd2B. Moreover, HMSNs without Pd treated by DMAB in the same solvothermal method show a B loading of ∼ 1.7 wt%, and the corresponding B 1 s XPS spectra in Figure S6b exhibit oxidized B species (no B0 species), further confirming that the majority of oxidized B species in Pd2B@HMSNs is due to the thermal decomposition of excess DMAB. Figure S7 presents the effect of the reaction temperatures on hydrogenation of 2-butyn-1-ol. The hydrogenation rates of Pd2B@HMSNs prepared from the boronation of Pd@HMSNs-400–200 are slow at the reaction temperature of 15 °C, and significantly increase at 30 °C. Further increasing the reaction temperatures to 45 °C reaches the best performance while continuously increasing to 60 °C shows a small difference, suggesting that the accelerating effect of increasing temperatures is offset by the reduction of dissolved H2 at higher reaction temperatures. Importantly, the yields of cis-2-buten-1-ol don’t decrease with the increase of reaction temperatures, confirming the robust inhibition of alkene adsorption by alloying Pd with B. Figure S8 illustrates the effect of solvents on the performance of Pd2B@HMSNs prepared from the boronation of Pd@HMSNs-400–200. Among ethanol, methanol and isopropanol, ethanol as solvents demonstrates the highest reaction rate and high cis-2-buten-1-ol yield, possibly due to the better dispersion of Pd2B@HMSNs in ethanol and enhanced mass transfer for reactions. Cycle-to-cycle experiments were performed to evaluate the reusability of Pd2B@HMSNs prepared from the boronation of Pd@HMSNs-400–200. The reactions were performed at 45 °C and ethanol as solvents (the blue curve in Figure S7). After each run, the catalysts were collected, washed by ethanol and dried at 60 °C overnight for the next cycle. Recovery process will cause some loss of catalysts. To keep the same reaction conditions, the ratios of solvents/substrates/catalysts were kept constant according to the weight of the collected catalysts during the recycling experiments. As shown in Table 2, complete conversion and 100 % of cis-2-buten-1-ol selectivity are achieved in cycle 1 while 98.8 % of conversion and 93.4 % of selectivity are obtained in cycle 5, showing less performance degradation during recycling experiments. This good catalytic stability is originated from the good structural stability. Hot filtration experiments didn’t show continuous reactions after the catalysts were separated from the reaction system, suggesting no apparent metal leaching into the solution. Moreover, HAADF-STEM images of Pd2B@HMSNs prepared from the boronation of Pd@HMSNs-400–200 before (Fig. 1a) and after recycling experiments (Figure S9a) don’t show apparent difference. Furthermore, the size of inner NPs (the insert in Figure S9a) and XRD patterns (Figure S9b) after reactions don’t show an obvious change, further confirming the structural stability. 3 Conclusion In this study, hollow mesoporous silica nanospheres-encaged Pd2B alloy NPs (Pd2B@HMSNs) were prepared by in situ transformation of Pd@HMSNs with borane dimethylamine complex by a solvothermal method. Such an in situ method preserves the small size of catalytic functionality and the protection of shells to inner NPs. The obtained Pd2B@HMSNs exhibit good hydrogenation rates and extremely high selectivity of alkene formation for hydrogenations of a series of alkyne. Especially, the high alkene selectivity can be maintained with an extended reaction time, and extremely high cis to trans alkene selectivity are achieved for those internal alkynes. The catalytic enhancement of Pd2B@HMSNs is ascribed to the change of electronic and geometric properties of surface Pd species due to alloying Pd with B. We believe that such hollow mesoporous silica nanosphere-encaged metal-metalloid alloys could find more applications in heterogeneous catalytic reactions, and the use of such alloys may enhance the selectivity for hydrogenations of multi-groups substituted substrates. 4 Experimental section 4.1 Synthesis of Pd@HMSNs-400–200 and Pd@HMSNs-500–200 A portion of 1.620 g of PAA aqueous solution and 1.467 g of PEI were mixed with 18.0 mL of aqueous ammonia and 1.2 mL of deionized water at room temperature. The resulting mixture was stirred at 600 rpm to obtain a clear solution. Then, 2.0 mL of the above mentioned mixture were mixed with 28.0 g of ethanol, which was followed by slow addition of 0.24 mL of TMOS under vigorous stirring. After further stirring for 10.0 mins, the solids were collected by centrifugation and washing with deionized water three times. The above collected solids were re-dispersed in 15.0 mL deionized water, and then soaked in 15.0 mL of 0.50 mM K2PdCl4 in 0.010 M HCl aqueous solution. After stirring for another 12 hrs, the solid products were collected by centrifugation, washing with deionized water three times, and drying in an oven at 60 °C overnight. Finally, the solids were calcined for 3.0 hrs at 400 or 500 °C with a ramping rate of 0.8 °C/min in a muffle furnace, and subsequently reduced with H2 for 3.0 hrs at 200 °C to obtain Pd@HMSNs-400–200 or Pd@HMSNs-500–200, respectively. The Pd loadings of Pd@HMSNs-400–200 or Pd@HMSNs-500–200 determined by ICP-OES are 0.22 and 0.29 wt%, respectively. 4.2 Synthesis of Pd2B@HMSNs prepared from the boronation of Pd@HMSNs-400–200 and Pd2B@HMSNs prepared from the boronation of Pd@HMSNs-500–200 A portion of 50 mg Pd@HMSNs-400–200 or Pd@HMSNs-500–200 and 600 mg borane dimethylamine complex (DMAB) were mixed with 10 mL of tetrahydrofuran, and further sonicated for 30 mins. Then, the mixture was transferred to a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless hydrothermal reactor, and further solvothermally treated at 160 °C for 5 hrs. The solids were collected by centrifugation, washing with tetrahydrofuran and EtOH several times, and drying in an oven at 60 °C overnight to obtain Pd2B@HMSNs prepared from the boronation of Pd@HMSNs-400–200 and Pd2B@HMSNs prepared from the boronation of Pd@HMSNs-500–200. The Pd loadings of Pd2B@HMSNs prepared from the boronation of Pd@HMSNs-400–200 and Pd2B@HMSNs prepared from the boronation of Pd@HMSNs-500–200 are 0.27 and 0.30 wt%, respectively. 4.3 Catalytic activity measurement Typically, a desired amount of various catalysts, 1.0 mmol of various substrates and 10.0 mL of the desired solvents were charged into a 25 mL three-necked round-bottomed flask. The hydrogenation reactions were performed at atmospheric H2 pressure and the defined reaction temperature under vigorous magnetic stirring at 800 rpm. The liquid hydrogenation products were sampled at the defined time intervals and analyzed by a gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a flame ionization detector. The detailed GC analysis method was shown in Supporting Information. The cycle to cycle experiments were carried out under atmospheric H2 pressure and the defined reaction temperature under vigorous magnetic stirring at 800 rpm, and the ratios of catalysts/substrates/solvents during the stability test were kept constant according to the weight of the recovered catalysts. coredata.dc:description: In this work, we report metal-metalloid Pd2B alloy nanoparticles as highly efficient and selective catalysts for semi-hydrogenations of alkynes. The mentioned materials feature the residence of small Pd2B nanoparticles in the cavities of hollow mesoporous silica nanospheres (Pd2B@HMSNs), and were synthesized by in situ transformation of Pd@HMSNs with B sources. At near room temperatures and atmospheric H2 pressure, Pd2B@HMSNs exhibited high alkene selectivity for hydrogenations of a series of alkynes. Especially, such high alkene selectivity can be maintained with a prolonged reaction time, and nearly 100 % selectivity of cis to trans alkene is obtained for those internal alkynes. The excellent performance of Pd2B@HMSNs is originated from the residence of catalytic functionality inside hollow nanostructures and the change of electronic/geometric properties of surface Pd species by alloying with B, where the former improves their reusability and the latter suppresses the deep-hydrogenation of alkenes.
